basics.name: James Hurcomb
basics.label: Toxicologist
basics.summary:
Final-year PhD student in toxicology with experience studying drug impacts across multiple organ systems. Skilled
in research, data analysis, and scientific communication. Keen to apply expertise gained through academic study to
exciting new problems.

location.region: Looking for opportunities across UK & Europe

work.company: MRC Toxicology Unit, University of Cambridge
highlights:
Undertook multiple projects investigating pathways of drug and environmental pollutant toxicity induced inter-organ communication with a focus on the
gastrointestinal system and whole-body metabolic homeostasis
Extensive experience with common molecular biology, biochemistry, and microscopy techniques
Analysed complex datasets using R and Python
Presented work in departmental seminars and at national and international conferences
Contributed to multiple peer-reviewed manuscripts and took part in outreach and public engagement work

Designed and delivered a series of weekly small group tutorials across three
            different first-year courses for medical and biological science students

Facilitated interactive discussions to reinforce key concepts, promote critical
            thinking, and enhance student understanding of complex biological processes

Provided personalized feedback and guidance to help students strengthen
            problem-solving skills, improve exam techniques, and succeed academically

Acted as a demonstrator for more than 30 practical classes across first/second
            years of medical and biological science courses teaching 50+ students per class
Overall responsibility for internal and external communications of the St. Edmund’s College Combination Room (Student’s Union)
Managed website and email list, drafted constitutional changes following student votes, and collaboratively determined policy direction with other committee members

courses: Studied at the MRC Toxicology Unit
Studied German A2 level in spare time

Studied a comprehensive course covering key concepts across the biological
sciences (Developmental Biology, Cell and Molecular Biology, Anatomy, Pathology), with a particular
focus in final year studies on Physiology and Pharmacology
